awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Strategies Used by Two-year Colleges to Support Academic Continuity in STEM Education During the COVID-19 Crisis
awd_abstract_narration:
Like other institutions of higher education, two-year institutions in the United States responded to the COVID-19 pandemic by using virtual instruction to provide academic continuity.  Many of these institutions turned to the use of Digital Learning Tools, such as e-curricula, e-learning simulations and laboratories, and virtual reality modules.  This pivot to online learning is expected to mitigate the disruption in the education of highly skilled professionals for the technical manufacturing workforce.  The project team will examine the immediate e-learning response of two-year institutions to the COVID-19 crisis by investigating the use of Digital Learning Tools, specifically the e-curricula/materials and virtual reality simulations and laboratories developed by the NSF-funded Center for Aviation and Automotive Technological Education Using Virtual E-Schools (CA2VES) project.  The goal of the project is to better understand the immediate e-learning responses of two-year institutions to the COVID-19 crisis, as well as the impact of these responses. 

Working closely with the South Carolina Technical College System and the National Center for Autonomous Technologies, the Clemson University-based research team will conduct a sequential exploratory research study that applies the Resilience Engineering Framework and the Technology Acceptance Model to address four research questions:  1) What demands were placed on two-year college educators during the rapid pandemic response? 2) What barriers to adoption and integration of e-learning resources did educators and students experience? 3) What strategies did administrators, educators, and students employ during the rapid transition? 4) What adaptations to e-learning do educators and students anticipate in the immediate future because of the COVID-19 pandemic?  The mixed methods study will investigate the demands placed on instructors, students, and administrators to understand the barriers in adopting and integrating e-learning resources into manufacturing programs by conducting field studies.  Based on the field studies, the project team will develop and administer a national survey to document and examine the national landscape for strategies employed in the rapid transition to online learning.  The research team will systematically analyze and integrate quantitative and qualitative data to inform the development of evidence-based guidelines to strengthen academic continuity and the e-learning ecosystem.  They will disseminate research findings to a broad audience of stakeholders to guide effective rapid educational transitions under disruptive conditions.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 pandemic significantly disrupted two-year college programs, exposing critical gaps in digital learning readiness. This project investigated the resilience of two-year aviation and automotive technician education programs in response to the pandemic, focusing on their ability to maintain academic continuity through digital learning tools.  Utilizing a resilience engineering framework, the project assessed institutional adaptive capacities through surveys and qualitative analysis of 43 interviews with students, instructors, and administrators. Key findings indicated that the sudden shift to remote instruction was hindered by inadequate preparedness, resource constraints, and regulatory hurdles, such as FAA approval processes for distance learning. Programs that had previously integrated digital learning tools demonstrated greater adaptability, whereas those reliant on traditional hands-on instruction experienced significant disruptions. The study identified major challenges, including the inability to replicate kinesthetic learning in a virtual environment, increased instructor workload, and a lack of structured peer engagement among students. The project highlighted the necessity of hybrid instructional models that combine synchronous and asynchronous learning, virtual and augmented reality-based simulations to enhance practical training, and targeted faculty development initiatives to improve digital literacy. To improve the scalability and sustainability of remote learning in technical education, the project recommended reducing access barriers through enhanced technology support and policy updates. The project also proposed a human-centered framework to guide the design and transition of labs to online platforms. It also developed a process for creating online labs using a human-centered design framework, addressing challenges such as technology limitations, workload constraints, and academic integrity. A follow-up study using simulations built with this process found that synchronous online labs incorporating video demonstrations and simulations were the most effective, enhancing engagement and comprehension. This framework was further applied to an aviation maintenance lab, where video demonstrations and VR simulations were compared for teaching fluid line fabrication. Results measured learning gains, task performance, workload, and usability, providing insights into effective online technician training methods.

The broader impact of this research extends to workforce development, institutional policy recommendations, and contributions to academic literature. Findings have been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, including New Directions for Community Colleges, Aviation Technician Education Journal and presentations at regional and national conferences. The project facilitated advanced research training for two graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher, equipping them with expertise in qualitative methodologies, data synthesis, and dissemination strategies. It also provided REU experiences to eight undergraduate students and two high school students, who conducted studies on the efficacy of digital learning environments. A MS thesis at Clemson University examined the effectiveness of VR-based simulations for aviation maintenance training, demonstrating improvements in procedural comprehension and learner engagement. This project informs future pedagogical frameworks for technical education, ensuring the resilience and adaptability of workforce training programs in response to emerging disruptions.
